Thanks everyone.

These are perfectly fine solutions. The only trouble for me was that I wanted
the suite to have an opportunity to track its test case runs and recover,
automatically. I may have a suite consisting of up to 20 or so test cases
and may be wrapped in a test harness class to run all suites.

I also toy with the tracking of threads for these runs and ended up with the
following solution (not quite content with it yet but works):

1) Created a synchronized test manager class
     and have it read a timeLimit property from a prop file (just for 
convenience)
2) It spawns a thread for a Runnable class to handle TestRunner.run(suite)
     then starts the count down
3) When the run() finishes, I flag a testComplete=true flag and notify() the
     manager class that the test run is done
4) Back in the manager class, if the time elapsed and not testComplete then
     I assume a test run fault. Kill the thread and throw exception 
(ThreadDeath
     error is also thrown from this class).
     Otherwise, a wait(timeLimit) gets the notification and testComplete=true
     implies the test completed successfully.

Since I use the Thread.stop()-deprecated to kill the spawning thread, I am not
content of this solution, at the very least.

The quest continues..

Again, thanks for your advices.
Thach Nguyen
